The autopilot will disengage, followed by the autothrottles retarding completely, then disengaging the auto throttle
Compressor stalls followed by engine failure

variant.question:

options.text: return to the de-icing area and have the aeroplane de-iced before applying another coat of anti-icing fluid.
return to the de-icing area and have the aeroplane surfaces applied with anti-icing fluid only.
operate the aeroplane wind screen wipers to disperse the snow.
ask fort he different taxi route and expedite to the runway for an immediate take-off provided the holdover time has not been exceeded.

An increased climb rate and airspeed

variant.question:
What is the best definition of the term "Frost"
A deposit of ice .....

options.text: with a crystalline appearance, formed when water vapour freezes directly onto a surface that has a temperature at or below 0° C.
that is clear, formed when supercooled water droplets freeze directly onto a surface that has a temperature and dew point at or below 0° C.
formed when snowflakes freeze directly onto a surface that has a temperature at or below 0° C.
that is clear, formed when water droplets freeze directly onto a surface that has a temperature at or below 0° C, regardless of the dew point.

variant.question: An aeroplane has been chartered to transport a group of passengers. Catering is being loaded onto the aeroplane and it includes perishable food items that are being kept cold by packets of dry ice. During passenger boarding, one of the passengers, who is a chef, has food and dry ice in his/her cabin baggage. Is there any difference in the way the dry ice is considered?

options.text: Yes, the dry ice used for catering is part of the aeroplane equipment while the dry ice brought by the chef is controlled by the Technical Instructions for Dangerous Goods.
Yes, the dry ice used for aeroplane catering must be a different type of dry ice compared to what may be carried by passengers and only dry ice carried by passengers is subject to restrictions.
No, the dry ice used for catering and by the passenger is the same substance, there are NO restrictions regarding how much may be carried and it can be stored in any part approved for baggage.

No, the dry ice used for catering and by the passenger is the same substance, and the same restrictions regarding the quantity and packaging are established in the Technical Instructions for Dangerous Goods.

variant.question: During the taxi out to the runway for departure after a quick turnaround at Geneva, Switzerland (LSGG), freezing rain starts to fall. What effect, if any, might this have on the planned take-off?

options.text: Ice may have formed on the pitot tubes, giving false airspeed indications; de-icing and anti-icing will therefore be required.
Ice may have formed on the pitot tubes, therefore the taxi speeds must be increased, and the rotation performed at a rate slightly below normal.

There is a high probability that the pitot tubes and static vents may have become blocked, but this will not affect the take-off speed indications, since the aircraft has already begun to taxi; the take-off may be performed.

There will be NO possible effects on any of the cockpit indications, although the aircraft external surfaces should be checked for any ice deposits and the "clean aircraft" requirements satisfied before attempting to take-off.

variant.question: A crew have just landed at Cologne, Germany where the temperature is -10° C and there is a large accumulation of frost on the underside of the wings. options.text: The aircraft must be de-iced and anti-iced prior to take-off to comply with the "clean aircraft concept".

Inform the ground crew that a very quick turnaround is required in order to avoid the freezing rain accumulating significantly on the aircraft.

variant.question: How might icing encountered on the ground, rather than in the air, pose more of a threat to an aircraft operation?

De-icing fluid tends to remain on critical flight surfaces when the aircraft is on the ground and may become a hazard.
